snippet.textDisplay: IMO there is a misinterpretation of evolution here. Adaptive changes are waaay less common than deleterious changes. So my bet with the case of the Lactase gene is that, somehow, in Europe at some point was a selective advantage to express it as an adult because most other people were starving. In other places, likely, this selection never happened, they never got so reliant on animal milk,  so the gene remained unexpressed in adulthood.
snippet.textOriginal: IMO there is a misinterpretation of evolution here. Adaptive changes are waaay less common than deleterious changes. So my bet with the case of the Lactase gene is that, somehow, in Europe at some point was a selective advantage to express it as an adult because most other people were starving. In other places, likely, this selection never happened, they never got so reliant on animal milk,  so the gene remained unexpressed in adulthood.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yeah, so I'm going to take a pretty hardline stance on this.
Milk is healthy but, given that alternatives to it are equally so and not destroying the earth, it should be abandoned sans doubt. We might say this is the fault of profit-seeking companies rather than the product itself. Still, the reality of the situation is that it's primarily the product of needing to supply an enormous number of people rather than the unwillingness to optimize. Until milk is sustainable, we shouldn't drink it.


(Elaboration: Assuming you live in a poor country in which you literally need milk to survive, then it's absolutely fine. As far as I'm aware, you shouldn't have a significant impact on climate anyway.)
snippet.textOriginal:
Yeah, so I'm going to take a pretty hardline stance on this. 
Milk is healthy but, given that alternatives to it are equally so and not destroying the earth, it should be abandoned sans doubt. We might say this is the fault of profit-seeking companies rather than the product itself. Still, the reality of the situation is that it's primarily the product of needing to supply an enormous number of people rather than the unwillingness to optimize. Until milk is sustainable, we shouldn't drink it.


(Elaboration: Assuming you live in a poor country in which you literally need milk to survive, then it's absolutely fine. As far as I'm aware, you shouldn't have a significant impact on climate anyway.)

snippet.textDisplay:
my family bake a lot, so i need milk, cream and butter quite frequently, but at the same time, if mass produced dairy farms all shut down and meant we had to look for local sources of dairy (or even produce our own) which may not be available all year round. i'd be absolutely fine with that, it would be ideal!


a thing that annoys me is when its suggested that its the general consumers fault for the way that the dairy industry is the way it is. of course it's something people should be aware of, but also massive industries like that shouldn't need permission from its consumers to be... more ethical? they should just do it anyway?
again i know it's not that simple and people wont "just do that". but, ykno, it's a bit aggravating.


very interesting about the lactose percentages though! i had no idea it was that high of a thing around the world!

snippet.textDisplay:
I love Kurgesagt and the videos they do they are amazing but I have one problem about this video and really with everyone that says shit about cows and their babies (calfs) being tortured. First of all not all cows are tortured yes some farms do keep cows in close quarters but not all of them cows are looked after well by farmers, where they sleep is cleaned at least twice a day, they are fed regularly they, they have plenty of space and they are get to go outside into fields to graze grass and run around. The second thing that I want everyone to know because there's a load of shit about this but taking the baby (I'm going to call them calfs from now on) from the mother is NOT BAD for the calf. Farmers milk the cow and give that milk to her calf. The calfs are well fed, their living area is very clean, If they are sick they can be cured very quickly because of the farmers and they have plenty of space and they are mixed in with other calfs so they aren't alone.
I know this is a lot but look everyone needs to know what really goes on an average dairy farm

The second thing that I want everyone to know because there's a load of shit about this but taking the baby (I'm going to call them calfs from now on) from the mother is NOT BAD for the calf. Farmers milk the cow and give that milk to her calf. The calfs are well fed, their living area is very clean, If they are sick they can be cured very quickly because of the farmers and they have plenty of space and they are mixed in with other calfs so they aren't alone.
I know this is a lot but look everyone needs to know what really goes on an average dairy farm

snippet.textDisplay:
The cancer milk studies did NOT say milk increases your risk of cancer.
What they did conclude is people with cancer who drink more than 2 glasses of milk a day have a higher likelihood of the cancer becoming advanced. This of course is true of consuming ANY sugar rich food. Cancer cells require lots of sugar. Cancer diets are low sugar. This means no juice or sodas (which are high in sucrose and fructose) , or milk (which is high in lactose).

The bone fracture study simply found a correlation between milk drinkers and fractures. This is like saying there are more shark attacks when ice cream sales are high. Of course ice cream does not cause shark attacks. But:

Summer -> more ice cream
&
Summer-> more swimmers -> more shark attacks

Similarly:
Health conscious people -> drink milk and juice more (instead of sodas or beer)
&
Health conscious people -> are more physically active -> are more likely to engage in activities that might result in fractures.

People rarely fracture a bone by sitting on a couch watching TV drinking soda or beer.
snippet.textOriginal:
*The cancer milk studies* did NOT say milk increases your risk of cancer.
What they did conclude is people with cancer who drink more than 2 glasses of milk a day have a higher likelihood of the cancer becoming advanced. This of course is true of consuming ANY sugar rich food. Cancer cells require lots of sugar. Cancer diets are low sugar. This means no juice or sodas (which are high in sucrose and fructose) , or milk (which is high in lactose).

*The bone fracture study* simply found a correlation between milk drinkers and fractures. This is like saying there are more shark attacks when ice cream sales are high. Of course ice cream does not cause shark attacks. But:

Summer -> more ice cream
&
Summer-> more swimmers -> more shark attacks

Similarly:
Health conscious people -> drink milk and juice more (instead of sodas or beer) 
&
Health conscious people -> are more physically active -> are more likely to engage in activities that might result in fractures.

People rarely fracture a bone by sitting on a couch watching TV drinking soda or beer.

snippet.textDisplay: You missed the most important part of the milk conversation. Raw milk. The milk from a mother is raw milk. It’s the healthiest thing for the new born baby. It has live bacteria which is essential for proper digestion. 65% of babies aren’t lactose intolerant to their own mothers milk... Why? Because it’s raw. 65% of people are lactose intolerant to pasteurised milk. Heat treated so that the bacteria is killed. That’s all people drink nowadays. Pasteurised milk. Return to nature’s way and you will be in good health.
snippet.textOriginal: You missed the most important part of the milk conversation. Raw milk. The milk from a mother is raw milk. It’s the healthiest thing for the new born baby. snippet.textDisplay: Humans can't eat what dairy animals eat. But humans can consume what dairy animals produce. Plant based milk substitutes are produced only from foods that humans can eat but not necessarily from foods that animals consume. So more arable land is taken for human consumption, not animal consumption. Sounds like environmental greed.
snippet.textOriginal: Humans can't eat what dairy animals eat. But humans can consume what dairy animals produce. Plant based milk substitutes are produced only from foods that humans can eat but not necessarily from foods that animals consume. So more arable land is taken for human consumption, not animal consumption. Sounds like environmental greed.

This used to be a informational channel where I would come to learn about a topic and gain further insights. Many of the recent videos are just comparisons of different opinions about some topic. It's no longer a channel which teaches now concepts and explains a particular concept on detail.

snippet.textDisplay: I found out a couple of years ago that I have a rare casein protein allergy. Rather than regular discomfort from most dairy allergies, it affects my immune system over a long time, eventually leading to lethargy and depression. Apparently allergies can pop up at any time in life. I can no longer eat dairy. :( I miss icecream
snippet.textOriginal: I found out a couple of years ago that I have a rare casein protein allergy. Rather than regular discomfort from most dairy allergies, it affects my immune system over a long time, eventually leading to lethargy and depression. Apparently allergies can pop up at any time in life. I can no longer eat dairy. :( I miss icecream

snippet.textDisplay: We need more sustainable farming methods. Like perhaps smaller, more local farms. Less industrialized, less large corporate greed and corporate interests. Family farms, regional farms, local milk, less cows, less mistreatment, less environmental impact, especially when cows are given foods they naturally eat, and not foods that cause them to produce even more methane gas.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem is, that milk, the way we used to consume it, doesn’t exist anymore. We now drink milk, from cows, that are injected with crap, have growth hormones in their system and antibiotics. The milk they produce is then heated, to the point of destroying most nutrients, and becoming acidic, which causes calcium to be pulled from the bones, instead of depositing it. ( studies have shown osteoporosis to develop because of this)They then add synthetic calcium and vitamin d back into the mixture. The puss from infections is still in there too, pasteurization doesn’t mean filtration.

We as people, used to live more tribal, and drank unpasteurized, raw milk, mostly from sheep and goats. Babies can survive off goats milk, they can’t on cows milk. Cows milk and humans are incompatible.

It is meant to grow a calf , into an enormous size, in a very short time, and even those babies, stop drinking it after a while, and move on to solids and water. So should we.
snippet.textOriginal:
The problem is, that milk, the way we used to consume it, doesn’t exist anymore. We now drink milk, from cows, that are injected with crap, have growth hormones in their system and antibiotics. The milk they produce is then heated, to the point of destroying most nutrients, and becoming acidic, which causes calcium to be pulled from the bones, instead of depositing it. ( studies have shown osteoporosis to develop because of this)They then add synthetic calcium and vitamin d back into the mixture. The puss from infections is still in there too, pasteurization doesn’t mean filtration. 

We as people, used to live more tribal, and drank unpasteurized, raw milk, mostly from sheep and goats. Babies can survive off goats milk, they can’t on cows milk. Cows milk and humans are incompatible.

It is meant to grow a calf , into an enormous size, in a very short time, and even those babies, stop drinking it after a while, and move on to solids and water. So should we.
